RT @MattLesJ: @1GaryGannon Cannot argue with a word said. I pass those two buildings numerous times during the day and its shameful what isâ€¦
@noelmcgra13 Ah thanks Noel! Appreciate the nice words my friends.
@MarshaGertie It is!
become the basis of Inner City rejuvenation.

It is the culture of the Inner City and itâ€™s people that remains the best possibility for any redevelopment that would be sustainable long term.
The assets are already there that we can use. Itâ€™s our culture, our histories (the good, & the bad parts), our people that should

Instead, itâ€™s to be an office block. The old Magdalene Laundry to be a no frills hotel. Weâ€™re told that these will help the inner City but nobody actually believes that. Theyâ€™ll just erode the character & isolate the community further.

A theatre of magnificence that would attract people to the community. An artistic space along the lines of the Tate Modern that would become the heartbeat of the local economy where cafes, & smaller artistic hubs could spring up around it as a consequence of its vitality.

A stones throw up the road is Aldborough House. One of the finest Georgian Houses of itâ€™s type that remains standing anywhere. Imagine the potential for that site had the State not decided to sell it off..
It could have been the jewel in the crown of the Northside.

Itâ€™s a two acre site so we could also place much needed public housing there. In particular, single unit accommodation for older people would be a gorgeous & a suitable tonic to the hardship that occurred there for well over a century.

The old Magdalene Laundry to become a proper Social History museum that first commemorates, & seeks to be a place of understanding & reckoning for our Century of State Incarceration that included Magdalene Laundries; Mother & Baby Homes; Industrial Schools; asylums etc.

Imagine the potential for Inner City redevelopment that didnâ€™t consist of selling off the family jewels to private ownership.
Rutland St could become a hub for community services: childcare facilities, educational programmes, a youth centre, community garden.

Originally, and possibly still but theyâ€™ll no longer admit it, the profits from the sale of the old Magdalene Laundry on Sean McDermott was to be used to refurbish this building.
It was the sneakiest part of Enda Kennyâ€™s/ @FineGael promises to the Inner City.

Itâ€™s an extraordinary building though which could be the centre of Inner City rejuvenation.
Itâ€™s been about 24 years since the LYCS (community group that runs services from the back of it) were 1st promised its redevelopment.

Known locally as â€˜The Red Brick Slaughter House.â€™
My Ma was chased out of this school aged 12, never to return because she opportunistically tripped up a nun who would often beat her.
She has no regrets about it.
She later learned to read & write when she was in her 30s. https://t.co/BKyQvemEbx
